(<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib76\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib76\">2003</a>) find that for elliptical galaxies, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"${R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> is related to <em>M</em><sub><em>R</em></sub> via</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn33\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn33.gif\" alt=\"Equation (33)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\mathrm{log}\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\bar{R}}_{e}}{1\\,\\mathrm{kpc}}\\right)=-0.4{{aM}}_{R,c}+b,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t33\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn34\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn34.gif\" alt=\"Equation (34)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{M}_{R,c}={M}_{R}+5\\mathrm{log}\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{0.7}{h}\\right).\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t34\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Fitting to data from SDSS, Shen et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib76\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib76\">2003</a>) find <em>a</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.65 and <em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22125.06. For S0/a-b and late-type/spiral galaxies, they find</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn35\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn35.gif\" alt=\"Equation (35)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}\\begin{array}{rcl}\\mathrm{log}\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\bar{R}}_{e}}{1\\,\\mathrm{kpc}}\\right) & = & -0.4\\alpha {M}_{R,c}+(\\beta -\\alpha )\\\\ & & \\times \\,\\mathrm{log}\\left[1\\right.+\\ \\left.{10}^{-0.4({M}_{R,c}-{M}_{0})}\\right]+\\gamma ,\\end{array}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t35\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where fitting the SDSS data give <em>\u03b1</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.26, <em>\u03b2</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.51, <em>\u03b3</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.71, and <em>M</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221220.91. The dispersion in the size\u2013luminosity relation is given by</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn36\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn36.gif\" alt=\"Equation (36)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{log}{R}_{e}}={\\sigma }_{2}+\\displaystyle \\frac{({\\sigma }_{1}-{\\sigma }_{2})}{1+{10}^{-0.8({M}_{R,c}-{M}_{0})}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t36\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>for all galaxy types, with <em>\u03c3</em><sub>1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.45 and <em>\u03c3</em><sub>2</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.27. Having calculated <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn25.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{log}{R}_{e}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{log}{R}_{e}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn26.gif\" alt=\"${\\bar{R}}_{e}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\bar{R}}_{e}</script></span></span> given <em>M</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>, we can sample a value of log <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn27.gif\" alt=\"${R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> using Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn32\">32</a>).</p><p>The next steps are to draw the host galaxy ellipticity <em>e</em>'' and position angle <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn28.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }</script></span></span>. We take the host galaxy orientation to be random,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn37\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn37.gif\" alt=\"Equation (37)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }\\sim U[0,2\\pi ],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t37\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and to draw ellipticities, we use the results of the Cosmic Evolution Survey (COSMOS; Scoville et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib74\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib74\">2007</a>). COSMOS is a survey designed to probe the correlated evolution of galaxies, star formation, active galactic nuclei, and dark matter with large-scale structure. Our access point to COSMOS is the Advanced Camera for Surveys General Catalog (ACS-GC; Griffith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib28\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib28\">2012</a>). ACS-GC is a photometric and morphological database containing fits of structural parameters to publicly available data obtained with the ACS instrument on board <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>). The catalog was created using the code <tt>Galapagos</tt> (H\u00e4u\u00dfler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib36\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib36\">2007</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib35\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib35\">2011</a>), which incorporates the source extraction and photometry software SExtractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib5\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib5\">1996</a>) and the galaxy light profile fitting algorithm GALFIT (Peng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib62\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib62\">2002</a>). ACS-GC contains photometry and structural parameters for approximately 305,000 objects (both compact and extended) from COSMOS. The COSMOS images were taken with the Wide Field Camera (WFC) on ACS, through the F814W filter, a broad <em>i</em>-band filter spanning the wavelength range 7000\u20139600 \u00c5, with a scale of 0.05 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> and a resolution of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />09 FWHM.</p><p>We apply the cuts of Gupta et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib30\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib30\">2016</a>) to create a list of potential supernova host galaxies from the ACS-GC. We further subdivide this list into two groups: \"early\"- and \"late\"-type galaxies, having fitted values of the S\u00e9rsic index in the ACS-GC of <em>n</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a02.5 and <em>n</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a02.5, respectively. For elliptical hosts, we draw <em>e</em>'' at random from the fitted ellipticity values of the \"early\" group, and for S0/a-b and late-type/spiral hosts, we draw <em>e</em>'' at random from the fitted ellipticity values of the \"late\"-type group.</p><p>The last parameters to draw are the unlensed coordinates of the host galaxy centroid <em>x</em><sub><em>h</em></sub> and <em>y</em><sub><em>h</em></sub>. Here we take the probability density function (PDF) of supernova positions within the host galaxy to be directly proportional to the light profile, an assumption that has been borne out by observational studies that show supernova positions follow host light (e.g., Kelly &amp; Kirshner <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib41\">2012</a>). Thus we sample offsets \u0394<em>x</em> and \u0394<em>y</em> at random from the host galaxy light profile, and then take</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn38\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn38.gif\" alt=\"Equation (38)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{x}_{h}={x}_{s}-{\\rm{\\Delta }}x,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t38\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn39\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn39.gif\" alt=\"Equation (39)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{y}_{h}={y}_{s}-{\\rm{\\Delta }}y.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t39\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>The host galaxy light profiles follow a S\u00e9rsic function, defined as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn40\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn40.gif\" alt=\"Equation (40)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&I({r}_{c})={I}_{e}\\exp \\left\\{-{b}_{n}\\left[{\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{r}_{c}}{{R}_{e}}\\right)}^{\\displaystyle \\frac{1}{n}}-1\\right]\\right\\},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t40\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>r</em><sub><em>c</em></sub> is an ellipticity-free, host-galaxy-centered radial coordinate, and <em>b</em><sub><em>n</em></sub> is a constant scalar solution to the equation</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn41\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn41.gif\" alt=\"Equation (41)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\gamma (2n;{b}_{n})=\\displaystyle \\frac{1}{2}{\\rm{\\Gamma }}(2n),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t41\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>in which \u0393 is the Gamma function and <em>\u03b3</em> is the incomplete Gamma function.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0fn2\">7</a></sup>\n To sample a position at random from the surface brightness profile, we first draw two random deviates <em>z</em> and <em>\u03b8</em>' uniformly:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn42\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn42.gif\" alt=\"Equation (42)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&z\\sim U[0,1],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t42\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn43\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn43.gif\" alt=\"Equation (43)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\theta }^{{\\prime} }\\sim U[0,2\\pi ].\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t43\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Using the sampled <em>z</em>, we solve the following equation<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0fn3\">8</a></sup>\n for <em>x</em>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn44\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn44.gif\" alt=\"Equation (44)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\gamma (2n;x)=z{\\rm{\\Gamma }}(2n),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t44\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>then convert <em>x</em> into the radial coordinate <em>r</em><sub><em>c</em></sub> (see, e.g., Graham &amp; Driver <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib27\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib27\">2005</a>):</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn45\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn45.gif\" alt=\"Equation (45)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{r}_{c}={R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }{\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{x}{{b}_{n}}\\right)}^{n}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t45\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We can now write the ellipticity-free host offsets \u0394<em>x</em><sub><em>c</em></sub> and \u0394<em>y</em><sub><em>c</em></sub> as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn46\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn46.gif\" alt=\"Equation (46)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\rm{\\Delta }}{x}_{c}={r}_{c}\\cos \\theta ,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t46\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn47\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn47.gif\" alt=\"Equation (47)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\rm{\\Delta }}{y}_{c}={r}_{c}\\sin \\theta .\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t47\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We add ellipticity to obtain \u0394<em>x</em><sub><em>e</em></sub> and \u0394<em>y</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn48\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn48.gif\" alt=\"Equation (48)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\rm{\\Delta }}{x}_{e}={\\rm{\\Delta }}{x}_{c}\\sqrt{1-e},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t48\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn49\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn49.gif\" alt=\"Equation (49)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\rm{\\Delta }}{y}_{e}={\\rm{\\Delta }}{y}_{c}/\\sqrt{1-e}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t49\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Finally, we account for the position angle of the host galaxy <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn31.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }</script></span></span> by applying a rotation matrix:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn50\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn50.gif\" alt=\"Equation (50)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\left(\\begin{array}{c}{\\rm{\\Delta }}x\\\\ {\\rm{\\Delta }}y\\end{array}\\right)={\\left(\\begin{array}{cc}\\cos {\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} } & \\sin {\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }\\\\ -\\sin {\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} } & \\cos {\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }\\end{array}\\right)}^{-1}\\left(\\begin{array}{c}{\\rm{\\Delta }}{x}_{e}\\\\ {\\rm{\\Delta }}{y}_{e}\\end{array}\\right).\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t50\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>With sampling prescriptions for <em>M</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn32.gif\" alt=\"${R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn33.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime\\prime} }</script></span></span>, <em>e</em>'', <em>x</em><sub><em>h</em></sub>, and <em>y</em><sub><em>h</em></sub>, we can realize host galaxy light profiles at random.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-5\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-5\">2.5.\u00a0Sky Distribution</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We assign a sky location to each system realized in our simulation, which in turn determines the sampling, signal-to-noise ratio, and filters of its simulated photometry. The sky location also controls the amount of Milky Way dust extinction each system experiences (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-6\">2.6</a>). To randomly assign a sky position to a gLSN system, we draw two random deviates <em>u</em> and <em>v</em> uniformly:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn51\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn51.gif\" alt=\"Equation (51)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&u\\sim U[0,1],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t51\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn52\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn52.gif\" alt=\"Equation (52)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&v\\sim U[0,1].\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t52\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We then convert these to equatorial coordinates <em>\u03b1</em> (R.A.) and <em>\u03b4</em> (decl.) via</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn53\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn53.gif\" alt=\"Equation (53)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\delta =\\displaystyle \\frac{180^\\circ \\times \\arccos (2v-1)}{\\pi }-90^\\circ \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t53\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn54\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn54.gif\" alt=\"Equation (54)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\alpha =360^\\circ \\times u.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t54\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>This sampling prescription ensures that systems are distributed uniformly over the celestial sphere.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-6\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-6\">2.6.\u00a0Extinction</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>After randomly assigning a sky location to each gLSN system, we use the <tt>sfdmap</tt><sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0fn4\">9</a></sup>\n\u00a0implementation of the extinction maps of Schlegel et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib72\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib72\">1998</a>), scaled to the recalibrated values of Schlafly &amp; Finkbeiner (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib71\">2011</a>), to calculate the associated Milky Way reddening value, <em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)<sub>MW</sub>. We then apply the extinction to the observer-frame spectral time series of the supernova images using a Cardelli et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib11\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib11\">1989</a>) reddening law with <em>R</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a03.1. In addition to extinction by dust in the Milky Way, gLSNe can suffer extinction by dust in their host galaxies. Here we assume the host galaxy reddening <em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)<sub>host</sub> is distributed according to the thermonuclear and core-collapse extinction distributions of Hatano et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib34\">1998</a>) for galaxies at random orientations, shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f3\">3</a>. We apply host extinction to the rest-frame spectral time series of the supernova images using a Cardelli et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib11\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib11\">1989</a>) reddening law with <em>R</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a03.1, the measured Galactic value. Amanullah et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib1\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib1\">2015</a>) showed that there is significant diversity in the value of <em>R</em><sub><em>V</em></sub> for the observed host galaxy extinction in SNe Ia, and similar conclusions were reached for certain types of core-collapse SNe in Stritzinger et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib81\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib81\">2018</a>). In particular, lower values of <em>R</em><sub><em>V</em></sub> are often found (see Bulla et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib10\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib10\">2018</a> for a proposed explanation). By selecting a value of <em>R</em><sub><em>V</em></sub> on the upper range observed, we are assuming a relatively large attenuation by dust, <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>R</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a0<em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>), that is, a conservative estimate of the SN brightness. We neglect extinction by dust in the lens galaxies, which may reduce yields by making lensed images fainter. iPTF16geu showed evidence of extinction due to lens galaxy dust at subkiloparsec offsets (Goobar et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib26\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib26\">2017</a>), but with only one event, the frequency and spatial distribution of lens galaxy dust remain unclear. ZTF and LSST will be able to better constrain lens galaxy dust extinction by producing large samples of gLSNe\u00a0Ia.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0<em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)<sub>host</sub> distributions for galaxies at random orientations, from Hatano et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib34\">1998</a>). Host reddenings for Type Ia, SN 1991T-like, and SN 1991bg-like supernovae are drawn from the thermonuclear curve. Host reddenings for SNe IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ib/c are drawn from the core-collapse curve.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f3\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f3\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-7\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-7\">2.7.\u00a0Simulated Surveys</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>To simulate realistic light curves and pixel cutouts of our lens systems as they would appear in a survey, we must account for the survey's unique observing strategy and conditions, instrumental properties, and visit schedule. To do this, we use the outputs of software tools that run survey simulations with given science-driven desirables, a software model of the telescope and its control system, and models of weather and other environmental variables. Such simulations produce observation histories, which are records of times, pointings, and associated environmental data and telescope activities throughout a simulated survey. These histories can be examined to assess whether a simulated survey would be useful for any particular purpose or interest. We adopt a common format for survey observation histories, consisting of a table with the following columns:</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>field</tt>:\u00a0Field ID of the observation.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>filter</tt>:\u00a0Filter in which the observation was taken.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>time</tt>:\u00a0MJD at which the observation began (the shutter-open time).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>exptime</tt>:\u00a0Integration time of the exposure.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">5.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>sky</tt>_<tt>counts</tt>_<tt>per</tt>_<tt>pixel</tt>:\u00a0Sky counts (in electrons) in each pixel. This is not a count rate, but the counts integrated over the entire exposure. This column can optionally also include counts due to other spatially uniform Poisson backgrounds, such as dark current.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">6.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>psf</tt>_<tt>sigma</tt>:\u00a0Standard deviation (in arcseconds) of the point-spread function (PSF), modeled as a Gaussian.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">7.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>ra</tt>:\u00a0R.A. of the center of the pointing.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">8.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>dec</tt>:\u00a0decl. of the center of the pointing.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">9.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>night</tt>\u00a0(optional): Integer ID specifying the night of the survey in which the observation was taken, used for grouping and stacking observations.</div></li></ul><p>In addition to the observation histories, we specify instrumental properties with the following parameters:</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>pix</tt>_<tt>scale</tt>:\u00a0Plate scale of the camera (arcsec/pixel).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>read</tt>_<tt>noise</tt>:\u00a0Read noise of the camera, in electrons.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>field</tt>_<tt>of</tt>_<tt>view</tt>:\u00a0Field of view of the imager, in deg<sup>2</sup>.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>collecting</tt>_<tt>area</tt>:\u00a0Collecting area of the telescope, in cm<sup>2</sup>.</div></li></ul><p>In this work, we consider two surveys, ZTF and LSST, the two largest imaging surveys at optical wavelengths during the periods 2018\u20132021 and 2021\u20132032, respectively. In the following subsections, we describe these surveys and the operations simulations that we use to realize their data.</p><h4 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-7-1\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-7-1\">2.7.1.\u00a0The Zwicky Transient Facility</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>ZTF is an ongoing time-domain imaging survey observing a minimum of 15,000 deg<sup>2</sup> in the <em>g</em> and <em>r </em>bands (<em>\u03b4</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0\u221230\u00b0) every three nights to a median depth of 20.5 mag, with transient alerts released in real time to the public.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0fn5\">10</a></sup>\n In 2018 March, ZTF began science operations, replacing its predecessor, the intermediate Palomar Transient Factory (iPTF), on the 1.2 m Oschin-Schmidt telescope (P48) at Palomar Observatory near San Diego, California. The chief advance of ZTF over iPTF is a new wide-field camera developed for the survey (Smith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib93\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib93\">2014</a>; Bell et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib92\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib92\">2018</a>). With its 47 deg<sup>2</sup> field of view, the ZTF camera can survey 3750 deg<sup>2</sup> per hour, making it roughly an order of magnitude faster than iPTF. In addition to the 15,000 deg<sup>2</sup> public survey, a subset of 1600 deg<sup>2</sup> is currently monitored three times per night in two filters as a part of the ZTF partnership survey. Half of the survey area is also monitored in the <em>i </em>band every four nights. The remaining 20% of the survey time is allocated to proposals from collaboration members affiliated with the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) on a competitive basis. We simulate data from all three ZTF programs in the present work using the simulated ZTF survey of Bellm et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib94\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib94\">2019</a>), which uses the same scheduler as the actual survey. The scheduler uses Gurobi optimization,<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0fn6\">11</a></sup>\n a technique for integer programming, to maximize the number of images, weighted by the volume surveyed per image, observed in acceptable cadence windows, while maintaining a balance between the public, partnership, and Caltech surveys. While the observing sequence determined by the scheduler in the simulation is reliable, the observing conditions used by the simulation are overly optimistic, predicting limiting magnitudes of ~21.5 in all filters. In reality, ZTF can only reach a limiting magnitude of 20.5 in any filter in a 30 s exposure. Therefore, in our simulation, we set the seeing FWHM to 2'', the survey median, and the limiting magnitude (5<em>\u03c3</em>) to 20.5 for all observations.</p></div><h4 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-7-2\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-7-2\">2.7.2.\u00a0The Large Synoptic Survey Telescope</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>LSST is a planned imaging experiment that will conduct at least two interleaved surveys: a \"wide-fast-deep\" (WFD) survey covering roughly 20,000 deg<sup>2</sup> in <em>ugrizy</em> every two to three weeks with 30 s exposures (<em>r</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0~\u00a024), and a \"deep-drilling\" survey covering a smaller area at a significantly higher cadence (LSST Science Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib54\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib54\">2017</a>). A new 8 m telescope and camera with a 9.6 deg<sup>2</sup> field of view and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />2 pixels, located on the Cerro Pach\u00f3n ridge in northern Chile, are currently under construction to carry out the survey. First light and commissioning operations will begin in 2021, followed by science operations in 2022. The survey will collect data for 10 yr.</p><p>Several candidate observing strategies have been proposed for LSST. In this analysis, we evaluate two of the major ones from the perspective of gLSN science: a nominal observing strategy, known as <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt>, and a leading alternative, known as <tt>altsched</tt>. <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> divides its time between five interleaved surveys: a \"universal\" WFD survey (85.1%), a proposal to monitor the North Ecliptic Spur (6.5%), a proposal to monitor the Galactic plane (1.7%), a proposal to monitor the South Celestial Pole (2.2%), and a proposal to monitor five 9.6 deg<sup>2</sup> \"deep-drilling\" fields (4.5%). The median effective seeing (FWHM) for all proposals in the <em>r </em>band is 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />93. The median single-visit depths for the WFD fields are (23.14, 24.47, 24.16, 23.40, 22.23, 21.57) in the <em>ugrizy</em> bands.</p><p>The <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> simulation was performed using the software tool <tt>OpSim</tt> (Delgado et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib17\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib17\">2014</a>). <tt>OpSim</tt>\u00a0uses a greedy algorithm that chooses the best observation at a given time (according to a merit function based on the input science goals), with no look-ahead or long-term strategy. <tt>altsched</tt>, on the other hand, takes a simpler approach, following a preprogrammed path with no merit function. <tt>altsched</tt> attempts to observe fields at low air mass by observing only on the meridian, optimizing the signal-to-noise ratio of the observations. Like <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt>, <tt>altsched</tt> retains a dual visit per night requirement for transient artifact rejection and asteroid orbit linkage, but the two visits are taken in different filters, so colors can be obtained on all objects. <tt>altsched</tt> simulations of SN\u00a0Ia light curves have shown that the alternative cadence can lead to significantly better light curve sampling than <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt>. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s4\">4</a>, we evaluate both <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> and <tt>altsched</tt> for the LSST gLSN science case.</p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-8\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-8\">2.8.\u00a0Imaging, Photometry, and Calibration</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>To realize images and photometry of our simulated gLSN systems as they would appear in the mock surveys described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-7\">2.7</a>, we have developed an image-simulation pipeline based on the open-source astronomical image simulation code <tt>GalSim</tt>\u00a0 (Rowe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib69\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib69\">2015</a>) and the gravitational lensing code <tt>glafic</tt>\u00a0(Oguri <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib58\">2010</a>). For a given arrangement of supernova, host galaxy, and lens, we first solve the lens equation using <tt>glafic</tt> to determine the magnifications, time delays, multiplicities, and locations of the lensed supernova images. We then use <tt>glafic</tt> to solve the lens equation again for the magnification and surface brightness profile of the lensed host galaxy. With this information, we use <tt>GalSim</tt> to model the entire system. In <tt>GalSim</tt> parlance, we model each lensed supernova image as a <tt>DeltaFunction</tt>, the lens galaxy as a <tt>S\u00e9rsic</tt>, and the lensed host galaxy surface brightness profiles as <tt>InterpolatedImages</tt>. We convolve the model with a <tt>Gaussian</tt> model of the PSF, the width of which is provided by the survey simulation (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-7\">2.7</a>). We refer to the noiseless convolved model as <em>I</em>(<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) and the pixel values of the corresponding model image as <em>I</em><sub><em>xy</em></sub>. To generate an image for viewing, we add <tt>CCDNoise</tt> to the model consisting of Gaussian read noise, Poisson sky background, and Poisson source noise.</p><p>We perform photometry using a matched filter, following Bridle et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib9\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib9\">2009</a>). We assume we have a filter <em>w</em><sub><em>xy</em></sub> that perfectly matches the shape of the source and is normalized to 1: <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn34.gif\" alt=\"${w}_{{xy}}={I}_{{xy}}/\\sum {I}_{{xy}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{w}_{{xy}}={I}_{{xy}}/\\sum {I}_{{xy}}</script></span></span>. We calculate the measured signal as a weighted sum of the image and the filter, via</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn55\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn55.gif\" alt=\"Equation (55)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&S=\\displaystyle \\sum _{x,y}{w}_{{xy}}{I}_{{xy}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t55\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and we define the noise as the square root of the signal variance,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn56\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn56.gif\" alt=\"Equation (56)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&N=\\sqrt{\\mathrm{Var}(S)}={\\left[\\displaystyle \\sum _{x,y}{w}_{{xy}}^{2}{\\sigma }_{{xy}}^{2}\\right]}^{1/2},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t56\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn57\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn57.gif\" alt=\"Equation (57)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\sigma }_{{xy}}^{2}={\\mathrm{RN}}^{2}+{I}_{{xy}}+{B}_{{xy}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t57\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>In Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn57\">57</a>), RN is the read noise per pixel in e<sup>\u2212</sup>, and <em>B</em><sub><em>xy</em></sub> is the flux in e<sup>\u2212</sup> from the background (the sky, dark current, and so on) at pixel (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>). Finally, we determine the image zero point (ZP) via</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn58\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn58.gif\" alt=\"Equation (58)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\mathrm{ZP}=2.5\\mathrm{log}\\,S+m,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t58\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>m</em> is the apparent magnitude of the source through some filter in the AB system. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f4\">4</a> shows three example simulated images of the same gLSN system generated using our pipeline, taken with three different instruments under representative observing conditions.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Simulated <em>r</em>-band images of the same gLSN, taken at the same epoch, with three different instruments: ZTF (30 s integration), LSST (30 s integration), and <em>HST</em> (one orbit integration through F625W on WFC3). Each panel is 6''\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a06''. Only in the <em>HST</em> data can the resolved images of the transient be clearly seen; they are marked with arrows. ZTF and LSST will be unable to resolve the multiple images of most gLSNe, meaning high-resolution follow-up observations will be critical for lens modeling and time-delay extraction.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f4\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f4\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>To increase our sensitivity to faint transients, we stack observations taken in the same filter in a single night. For <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt>, this has the effect of combining the two exposures taken in the same filter in a ~30 minute window to reject moving objects into a single observation with a signal-to-noise ratio roughly a factor of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn35.gif\" alt=\"$\\sqrt{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sqrt{2}</script></span></span> larger. For <tt>altsched</tt>, the stacking has no effect, as the strategy performs revisits to reject moving objects in different filters to obtain colors. For ZTF, stacking has no effect on the public data, which has a typical revisit time of 3\u20134 days in each filter. However, the stacking significantly boosts survey depth in the high-cadence partnership fields and the Caltech survey. In some regions of these proprietary surveys, a single field may be observed as many as six times per night in a single filter, leading to a potential improvement in depth of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn36.gif\" alt=\"$2.5\\mathrm{log}(\\sqrt{6})\\approx 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.5\\mathrm{log}(\\sqrt{6})\\approx 1</script></span></span> mag over the nominal limiting magnitude of 20.5 in all filters. We apply the discovery technique discussed in the next section (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-9\">2.9</a>) to the stacked, not raw, data.</p><p>An important simplification in our simulations is that we treat gLSN images as a single object when performing photometry. The effect of this assumption is that we can realize a single light curve for each gLSN system, the flux of which is the summed flux of the individual images. For ZTF, this is a reasonable assumption, as the large pixels of the detector and the 2'' seeing at Palomar Observatory ensure gLSNe cannot be resolved (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f5\">5</a>). For LSST, as Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f6\">6</a> shows, this assumption should hold in most cases. For the cases where the assumption does not hold and the multiple images of a gLSN are resolved, the transient can be detected as two or more bright, nearby transients, as proposed by Oguri &amp; Marshall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib60\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib60\">2010</a>). For simplicity, we also assume perfect image subtractions. The main implication of this assumption is that photometric accuracy and source detection are unaffected by proximity to the cores of bright lens galaxies. In general, a loss in transient discovery efficiency can be caused by subtraction artifacts near the centers of bright galaxies. Because the point-source saturation limit for ZTF is <em>r</em>\u00a0~\u00a012.5 and the point-source saturation limit for LSST is <em>r</em>\u00a0~\u00a016, whereas candidate lens galaxies generally have <em>r</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a018, with the nearest ones being spatially extended (and thus having a lower equivalent surface brightness than their overall magnitude implies), this assumption is reasonable for gLSN searches.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Lens-centered difference image cutouts of 25 randomly selected ZTF gLSNe\u00a0Ia. The difference images are produced by subtracting deep references from science images stacked in 1-day bins. Each cutout is 25''\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a025''. The sources visible in the cutouts contain flux from the gLSN images only. Lens light and host galaxy light are removed in the subtraction. The low spatial resolution of ZTF (1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />01 pixels) combined with the 2'' FWHM seeing at Palomar Observatory render the survey unable to resolve multiply imaged supernovae, a feature we exploit in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-9\">2.9</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f5\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f5\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Lens-centered difference image cutouts of 25 randomly selected LSST (<tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt>) gLSNe\u00a0Ia. Each cutout is 7''\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a07''. As in Figure <a href=\"#apjsab1fe0f5\">5</a>, the sources visible in the cutouts contain flux from gLSN images only. Lens light and host galaxy light are removed in the subtraction. The improved spatial resolution (0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />2 pixels) of LSST compared to ZTF enables some gLSNe to be totally or marginally resolved, but the majority of systems remain unresolved. LSST must take special care to ensure that its machine learning algorithm for difference image artifact rejection (e.g., Goldstein et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib23\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib23\">2015</a>) does not reject marginally resolved gLSNe, such as the ones in row 5, column 1; row 1, column 4; and row 1, column 5.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f6\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f6\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-9\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-9\">2.9.\u00a0Discovery Technique</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We simulate the detection and photometric classification of gLSNe using the technique described in Section 4.1 of Goldstein et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>). The strategy leverages empirical trends to separate gLSNe from other nonlensed transients based on photometric information alone. The strategy can be summarized as follows:</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Systematically identify supernovae that are spatially coincident with elliptical galaxies (e.g., by cross-matching transient discoveries with an elliptical galaxy catalog).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Since elliptical galaxies can only host SNe\u00a0Ia, test the hypothesis that each supernova actually resides in the elliptical galaxy that appears to be its host by comparing the brightness, color evolution, and light curve shape of the supernova to those of an SN\u00a0Ia template at the photometric redshift of the elliptical galaxy.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">If the supernova is not consistent with being an SN\u00a0Ia hosted by the elliptical, then it is a candidate for being a lensed supernova at higher redshift.</div></li></ul><p>This technique does not apply to spiral galaxies, because spiral galaxies can host core-collapse supernovae, which have a much broader range of absolute magnitudes and light curve shapes than SNe\u00a0Ia.</p><p>In the present work, we assume that we have an elliptical galaxy catalog that is complete enough for all supernovae in our simulation to pass the first step in the procedure (i.e., no simulated supernovae are lost because they are lensed by an elliptical galaxy that is not cataloged). This assumption is reasonable in the era of ZTF and LSST, as wide-field multiband imaging surveys such as SDSS and Pan-STARRS have produced relatively complete catalogs of potential lens galaxies out to the redshifts we are interested in (<em>z</em>\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a01) in the northern sky. In the era of LSST, elliptical galaxy catalogs with complete photometric redshift coverage will be produced by LSST itself, and by precursor imaging surveys in the south such as the DECam Legacy Survey and the Dark Energy Survey. Additionally, wide-field multiobject spectroscopic surveys such as the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument will greatly increase the redshift completeness of current elliptical galaxy catalogs.</p><p>In the present analysis, as in Goldstein et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>), we use the SALT2 SN\u00a0Ia spectral template (Guy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib31\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib31\">2007</a>) to perform the second step of the discovery technique. We draw a random reference time <em>t</em><sub><em>r</em></sub> for each gLSN system uniformly over the duration of the survey,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn59\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn59.gif\" alt=\"Equation (59)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{t}_{r}\\sim U[{t}_{\\min },{t}_{\\max }],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t59\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>t</em><sub>min</sub> and <em>t</em><sub>max</sub> are the times of the survey's first and last observations, respectively. We realize broadband photometry of each blended gLSN\u00a0Ia using the technique described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-8\">2.8</a>. Starting from the first photometric observation of each gLSN system, we fit the blended light curve with SALT2, fixed to the redshift of the lens galaxy (assumed to be known; see the discussion above). We also enforce bounds on the fit parameters of the SN\u00a0Ia spectral template; see Section 4 of Goldstein et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>) for further details.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-10\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-10\">2.10.\u00a0Importance Sampling, Sample Weighting, and Rate Calculation</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We perform a separate Monte Carlo simulation for each survey and supernova type, running each simulation until <em>O</em>(10<sup>5</sup>) gLSN systems are discovered. In each iteration of the simulation, we realize one supernova behind the sampled lens in the lensing area of influence. We run each ZTF simulation for <em>N</em>\u00a0=\u00a010<sup>8</sup> iterations, and we run each LSST simulation for <em>N</em>\u00a0=\u00a010<sup>7</sup> iterations. The ZTF simulations require more iterations to converge because ZTF is shallower than LSST, so any given system is less likely to be detected. To reduce shot noise in our results, we use importance sampling to sample lens and source redshifts, the distributions of which contain almost no probability mass in the crucial region <em>z</em>\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a00.5. Therefore, each system has an associated importance weight factor <em>\u03c9</em>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn60\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn60.gif\" alt=\"Equation (60)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\omega =\\displaystyle \\frac{{f}_{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}}{{ \\mathcal A }}\\displaystyle \\frac{p({z}_{s})p({z}_{l})}{q({z}_{s})q({z}_{l})},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t60\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>p</em>(<em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>) and <em>p</em>(<em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>) are the true densities of <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> and <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> (Equations (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn14\">14</a>) and (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn30\">30</a>)), <em>q</em>(<em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>) and <em>q</em>(<em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>) are the sampling densities, <em>f</em><sub>\u03a9</sub> is the ratio of sky area imaged by the survey to the sky area covered in the simulation, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn37.gif\" alt=\"${ \\mathcal A }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{ \\mathcal A }</script></span></span> is the factor by which the supernova rate must be multiplied to yield one supernova of the given subtype with <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0<em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> per year in the \"lensing area of influence\" of the lens. We take the sampling densities to be uniform:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn61\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn61.gif\" alt=\"Equation (61)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&q({z}_{s})=U[{z}_{s,\\min },{z}_{s,\\max }],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t61\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn62\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn62.gif\" alt=\"Equation (62)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&q({z}_{l})=U[{z}_{l,\\min },{z}_{l,\\max }],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t62\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em>,min</sub> and <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em>,max</sub> are the minimum and maximum supernova redshifts considered in the simulation, respectively. We assume the lenses are uniformly distributed across the sky, so the areal correction factor <em>f</em><sub>\u03a9</sub> can be calculated by dividing the total number of lenses in the survey area by the number of lenses <em>N</em> realized in the simulation:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn63\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn63.gif\" alt=\"Equation (63)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{f}_{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\rm{\\Omega }}{D}_{H}}{N}{\\int }_{{\\sigma }_{\\min }}^{{\\sigma }_{\\max }}\\phi (\\sigma )\\,d\\sigma {\\int }_{{z}_{l,\\min }}^{{z}_{l,\\max }}\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\left(1+{z}_{l}\\right)}^{2}{D}_{l}^{2}}{E({z}_{l})}\\,{{dz}}_{l},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t63\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where we have integrated Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn11\">11</a>) to estimate the total number of lenses in the survey area. In Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn63\">63</a>), \u03a9 is the area of the survey in steradians, and <em>\u03c3</em><sub>min</sub> and <em>\u03c3</em><sub>max</sub> are the minimum and maximum lens velocity dispersions considered in the simulation, respectively.</p><p>The number of supernovae per year behind the lens's area of influence is determined by integrating the observer-frame supernova redshift function (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f1\">1</a>) from <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> or <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em>,min</sub> (whichever is larger) to <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em>,max</sub> and multiplying by the ratio of the lens's area of influence to the full-sky area. Taking <em>z</em><sub>1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0max(<em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>, <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em>,min</sub>) and <em>z</em><sub>2</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>z</em><sub><em>s</em>,max</sub>, we have</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn64\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn64.gif\" alt=\"Equation (64)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{ \\mathcal A }={\\left[\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\theta }_{l}^{2}}{4}{\\int }_{{z}_{1}}^{{z}_{2}}{f}_{T}({z}_{s}){{dz}}_{s}\\right]}^{-1}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t64\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>The weights specify the contribution of a given discovered system to the overall gLSN discovery rate and have units of [year<sup>\u22121</sup>]. The summed weights provide a Monte Carlo estimate of the gLSN discovery rate:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn65\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn65.gif\" alt=\"Equation (65)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\boxed{\\displaystyle \\displaystyle \\sum _{i=0}^{N}{\\omega }_{i}=R,}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t65\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>R</em> is the total discovery rate (in yr<sup>\u22121</sup>). As with any Monte Carlo estimator, the precision of <em>R</em> increases as the square root of the number of samples <em>N</em>. The above scheme is roughly 10<sup>3</sup> times more efficient than sampling all of the parameters of the model in a brute-force manner.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjsab1fe0s3\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s3\">3.\u00a0Results</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t2\">2</a> shows the gLSN discovery rates <em>R</em> of each simulated survey. Our calculations suggest that under nominal survey operations, ZTF should discover at least 8.60 gLSNe per year, of which at most 4.1% are Type Ib/c, 2.0% are SN 1991T-like, 3.7% are Type IIL, 14.3% are Type Ia, 32.1% are Type IIP, and 0.2% are SN 1991bg-like, and at least 43.6% are Type IIn. We find that the <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> LSST observing strategy should discover at least 380.60 gLSNe per year, of which at most 12.6% are Type Ia, 1.6% are SN 1991T-like, 23.3% are Type IIP, 4.1% are Type Ib/c, 3.4% are Type IIL, and 0.2% are SN 1991bg-like, and at least 55.0% are Type IIn. The <tt>altsched</tt> observing strategy should discover at least 341.27 gLSNe per year, of which at most 4.7% are Type Ib/c, 3.8% are Type IIL, 13.9% are Type Ia, 26.7% are Type IIP, 1.8% are SN 1991T-like, and 0.3% are SN 1991bg-like, and at least 45.3% are Type IIn. The Type IIn rates are given as lower limits because gLSNe\u00a0IIn can be detected in both ZTF and LSST beyond <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a03, the maximum redshift in our simulations, but their rate at <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a03 is highly speculative.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjsab1fe0t2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0\ngLSN Discovery Rates (in Units of Year<sup>\u22121</sup>) of ZTF and LSST\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0t2\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t2_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 2\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SN Type</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">ZTF</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">LSST (<tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt>)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">LSST (<tt>altsched</tt>)</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type Ia</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.23</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">47.84</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">47.42</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type IIP</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">2.76</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">88.51</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">91.06</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type IIn<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t2fna\">a</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">3.75</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">209.31</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">166.54</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type IIL</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.31</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">11.69</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">13.10</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type Ib/c</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.36</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">14.00</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">16.15</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SN 1991bg-like</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.02</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.79</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.89</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SN 1991T-like</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.17</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">5.41</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">6.09</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td class=\"rowsep\" colspan=\"4\" rowspan=\"1\">\n\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Total<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t2fna\">a</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">8.60</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">380.60</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">341.27</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjsab1fe0t2fna\" id=\"apjsab1fe0t2fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Lower limit.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t2_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4365/ab1fe0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t2_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Color-composite images of randomly selected gLSNe, drawn in proportion to their weights, discovered by ZTF and LSST (<tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt>) are shown in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f7\">7</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f8\">8</a>, respectively. Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f9\">9</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f10\">10</a> show the sky distributions of detected gLSNe. Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f11\">11</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f25\">25</a> summarize the results of our Monte Carlo simulations, presenting the distributions of several key observables and parameters of detected systems. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t3\">3</a> describes the subpanels in each figure, and red lines in histogram panels indicate medians. Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f26\">26</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f35\">35</a> show multiband light curves of gLSNe from ZTF and LSST. In those figures, the solid lines reflect the true underlying light curves of each image, while the photometric data are realized from the sum of the images. The ZTF photometry is unstacked, reflecting the survey's high intranight cadence, whereas the LSST photometry is combined nightly into single point per filter for clarity. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f36\">36</a> shows distributions of lensed host galaxy apparent magnitudes and separations (relative to the lens centroid) in units of <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>E</em></sub>.
