If the lens\u2013host centroid distance is less than 2<em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>E</em></sub>, there is a strong likelihood that the host galaxy is multiply imaged and can thus provide useful constraints on the lens model.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0Model (i.e., noiseless) 6''\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a06'' composite <em>gri</em> images of 25 randomly chosen simulated gLSNe, their lens galaxies, and their lensed host galaxies, \"detected\" by ZTF. Each image is \"taken\" exactly one night after the transient is detected as a gLSN candidate based on a light curve fit to the simulated ZTF data (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-9\">2.9</a>). The FWHM of the seeing on the images is 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />1, and the pixel scale is 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />04, identical to that of the UVIS channel of the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) on <em>HST</em>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f7\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f7\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Model (i.e., noiseless) 6''\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a06'' composite <em>gri</em> images of 25 randomly chosen simulated gLSNe, their lens galaxies, and their lensed host galaxies, \"detected\" by LSST under the <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> observing strategy. Each image is \"taken\" exactly one night after the transient is detected as a gLSN candidate based on a light curve fit to the simulated LSST data (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-9\">2.9</a>). The FWHM of the seeing on the images is 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />1, and the pixel scale is 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />04, identical to that of the UVIS channel of WFC3. The systems in this mosaic are generally less compact and less magnified than those in Figure <a href=\"#apjsab1fe0f7\">7</a>, reflecting the increased depth and red-sensitivity of LSST compared to ZTF.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f8\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f8\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; The lines show the model light curves of the individual images. The photometric data are realized from the sum of the model light curves. The images have time delays relative to the earliest image of 46.44, 42.42, and 76.43 days and lensing amplifications of 1.8, 1.4, 2.8, and 0.4. The lines show the model light curves of the individual images. The photometric data are realized from the sum of the model light curves.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f35\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f35\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f35\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f35\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjsab1fe0t3\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 3.</b>\u00a0\nDescription of the Subpanels in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f12\">12</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f24\">24</a>\n\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0t3\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t3_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 3\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"center\">Description</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">a</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Smallest angular separation, in arcseconds, between two images in the system (alternatively, the angular resolution required to completely resolve the system)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">b</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Largest time delay between two images in the system</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">c</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Rest-frame phase of the blended light curve on the date of discovery relative to rest-frame <em>B</em>-band maximum</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Peak observer-frame AB magnitude of the gLSN in <em>g</em> (ZTF) or <em>r</em> (LSST)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">e</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Peak observer-frame AB magnitude of the gLSN in <em>r</em> (ZTF) or <em>i</em> (LSST)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">f</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Peak observer-frame AB magnitude of the gLSN in <em>i</em> (ZTF) or <em>z</em> (LSST)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">g</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Source redshift</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">h</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Lens redshift</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">i</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Magnitude of the external shear</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">j</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SIE velocity dispersion</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">k</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Total lensing amplification of the gLSN images</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">l</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Number of gLSN images in the system</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">m</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Correlation between source and lens redshift, color coded by image multiplicity. Purple points correspond to double images, blue to quads, and redder colors to systems with more than four images.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Correlation between total magnification and image separation, color coded as (m)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">o</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Correlation between median image separation and median time delay, color coded as (m)</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t3_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4365/ab1fe0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t3_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f7\">7</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f8\">8</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f11\">11</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f17\">17</a>, and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f25\">25</a> show that ZTF and LSST are sensitive to different populations of gLSNe. ZTF gLSNe have a median <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.9, <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.35, <em>\u03bc</em><sub>tot</sub>\u00a0=\u00a030, \u0394<em>t</em><sub>max</sub>\u00a0=\u00a010 days, min <em>\u03b8</em>\u00a0=\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />25, and <em>N</em><sub>img</sub>\u00a0=\u00a04. LSST gLSNe have a median <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.0, <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.4, <em>\u03bc</em><sub>tot</sub>\u00a0\u2248\u00a06, \u0394<em>t</em><sub>max</sub>\u00a0=\u00a025 days, min <em>\u03b8</em>\u00a0=\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />6, and <em>N</em><sub>img</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02. Synthesizing this information, we find the ZTF gLSNe tend to be more compact, highly magnified, and have shorter time delays than their LSST counterparts. Additionally, ZTF gLSNe are more likely to be quads than gLSNe from LSST. The gLSN iPTF16geu discovered by ZTF's predecessor iPTF was broadly consistent with this picture: it was a compact (med <em>\u03b8</em>\u00a0~\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />3) and highly magnified (<em>\u03bc</em>\u00a0~\u00a090) quad with short time delays (\u0394<em>t</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01 day). The gLSNe from LSST will be better suited to time-delay cosmology. Their longer time delays and wider separations will enable more precise constraints on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and better models of the mass profile. However, they will be fainter and thus require larger telescopes and more observing time for follow-up observations. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t4\">4</a> shows that just 10% of the gLSNe that ZTF will find will come from the public data alone. The proprietary data, notably the high-cadence data and the <em>i</em>-band survey, will be critical for discovering gLSNe.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjsab1fe0t4\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 4.</b>\u00a0\nFraction of gLSNe Discovered in the ZTF Simulation That Have <em>i</em>-band Data (Partnership), High-cadence Data (Partnership), and Exclusively MSIP (Public Survey) Data\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0t4\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t4_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 4\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" [%]</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type Ia</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">77.7</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">77.3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">12.4</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type IIP</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">82.0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">73.9</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">10.5</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type IIn</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">71.3</td>\n<td align=\"left\">Type Ib/c</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">80.4</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">76.8</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">10.8</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Type IIL</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">81.1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">75.1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">10.7</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SN 1991bg-like</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">81.7</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">75.6</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">9.9</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SN 1991T-like</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">77.3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">75.5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">13.0</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t4_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4365/ab1fe0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t4_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjsab1fe0s4\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s4\">4.\u00a0Discussion</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s4-1\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s4-1\">4.1.\u00a0Comments on the LSST Observing Strategy</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Broadly speaking, candidate observing strategies for LSST can be arranged on a spectrum in which area and season length are traded for sampling and depth. In this analysis, we have investigated strategies from both ends of this spectrum. <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> covers a large area with relatively poor light curve sampling, while <tt>altsched</tt> covers a smaller area with better sampling and greater depth. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t2\">2</a> shows that the nominal LSST observing strategy <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> discovers roughly the same number of gLSNe as the alternative strategy <tt>altsched</tt>, and Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f17\">17</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f25\">25</a> show that the greatest difference in the gLSNe discovered under the two strategies is the discovery phase (see panel (c) of both figures). <tt>altsched</tt> discovers gLSNe earlier than <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> due to its higher-quality light curves. A key result of this analysis is that for LSST, the improved light curve sampling and depth of surveys like <tt>altsched</tt> can compensate for the corresponding loss in area or season length by discovering more gLSNe per square degree. Moreover, the simulated <tt>altsched</tt> survey only used 85% of the total LSST observing time, so it is possible that the <tt>altsched</tt> yields presented here are too low by a factor of ~1.17. Because the gLSN yields of <tt>altsched</tt> are comparable to those of <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt>, which has significantly more area (26,100 deg<sup>2</sup> compared to <tt>altsched</tt>'s 21,460 deg<sup>2</sup>),<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0fn7\">12</a></sup>\n but the resulting light curves have significantly better sampling and are discovered earlier, we conclude that <tt>altsched</tt> is a superior strategy for finding gLSNe, enabling faster spectroscopic follow-up and more observations of gLSNe while they are in the achromatic phase (Goldstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s4-2\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s4-2\">4.2.\u00a0Host Galaxy Properties and Implications for Lens Modeling</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f36\">36</a> suggests that in both ZTF and LSST, at least 90% of lensed host galaxy centroids will be within 2<em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>E</em></sub> of their associated lens galaxy centroids, making it extremely likely that they will be multiply imaged. The median apparent magnitudes of the hosts from both surveys are roughly 22 in the redder filters, placing them well within reach of space-based imaging facilities such as <em>HST</em>, <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em>, and <em>WFIRST</em>, and larger ground-based facilities, especially those with adaptive optics systems. Combined with the fact that gLSNe fade away, enabling a more precise reconstruction of the lensed hosts compared to lensed AGNs, this suggests that host galaxy modeling will not be a limiting factor in gLSN time-delay cosmology.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s4-3\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s4-3\">4.3.\u00a0Triple Images and Other Exotic Configurations</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f7\">7</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f8\">8</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f11\">11</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f25\">25</a> show that ZTF and LSST will occasionally discover gLSNe with three or more than four lensed images. These exotic configurations are uncommon but legitimate predictions of our population model. Triple image systems, such as row three, column five of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f8\">8</a>, are a consequence of ellipticity in the lens mass profile. When an SIE lens becomes sufficiently elliptical, part of its inner \"diamond\" caustic can extend beyond the outer \"oval caustic\" in a configuration known as a \"naked cusp\" (Collett &amp; Cunnington <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib16\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib16\">2016</a>). If a source is located in the naked cusp, it will form three adjacent lensed images in a curve around the mass profile.</p><p>gLSNe with more than four images are even rarer than gLSNe lensed by naked cusps, but they may still be discovered occasionally with LSST (it is extremely unlikely that ZTF will find any). They are a consequence of a nonzero core radius in the SIE lens potential, which itself is a consequence of ellipticity. If a supernova is located sufficiently close to the core of an elliptical SIE, it is possible that more than four images will form; in our simulations, systems with as many as eight images formed. These systems are extremely magnified, <em>\u03bc</em>\u00a0~\u00a010<sup>4</sup>\u201310<sup>6</sup>, and have vanishingly small time delays and separations. For this reason, they may be straightforward to detect, but will provide almost no useful information for cosmology. They may, however, enable high signal-to-noise ratio spectroscopy of very high redshift supernovae, for which spectroscopy cannot currently be obtained. This would be useful for studying the evolution of the supernova population with redshift.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s4-4\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s4-4\">4.4.\u00a0Bimodal Lens Redshift Distribution for ZTF gLSNe\u00a0Ia</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>As Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f12\">12</a>(h) and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f16\">16</a>(h) show, the lens redshift distributions for Type Ia and SN 1991T-like supernovae in ZTF are bimodal, with a first peak at <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.1 and a second at <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.4. This is due to a selection effect introduced by the discovery strategy described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-9\">2.9</a>, which biases the survey against discovering SNe\u00a0Ia with two images in lenses with <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a00.15. In such systems, the flux amplification from lensing, which is usually on the order of a factor of a few, compensates for the reduction in flux caused by the fact that the supernova is at a higher redshift than the lens galaxy, making the overall flux of the transient compatible with an SN\u00a0Ia hosted by the lens. Thus a dearth of gLSNe\u00a0Ia with two images occurs for <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a00.15, causing the bimodal distribution. Other types of gLSNe in ZTF do not have bimodal lens redshift distributions because of their core-collapse nature. The colors of core-collapse supernovae are so different from those of normal SNe\u00a0Ia that they are still identified by the discovery when their overall fluxes are consistent with those of SNe\u00a0Ia hosted by the lens galaxy.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s4-5\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s4-5\">4.5.\u00a0Prevalence of gLSNe\u00a0IIn</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Both ZTF and LSST will discover gLSNe\u00a0IIn more frequently than any other gLSN subtype. SN Refsdal at <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.49, the first identified gLSN with resolved images, was a peculiar type of interacting supernova, similar to a Type IIn (Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib40\">2016</a>). Relatively speaking, unlensed SNe IIn are uncommon, making up just 8%\u201312% of the observed core-collapse supernova rate (Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib51\">2011</a>). However, SNe IIn are extremely bright (roughly 2 mag brighter than SNe IIp) and blue. Their colors are so different from those of SNe Ia that they are trivially identified by the discovery strategy detailed in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-9\">2.9</a>. As their volumetric rate follows the star formation rate (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f1\">1</a>), they are extremely common at high redshift (e.g., Petrushevska et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib63\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib63\">2016</a>), just beyond the flux limit of most imaging surveys.</p><p>Flux amplification from gravitational lensing will allow future synoptic imaging surveys to tap into this high-redshift population. This will enable unprecedented spectroscopic studies of the high-redshift core-collapse and interacting supernova populations. While in general the evolution of SNe IIn is slow, with the SED dominated by a blackbody continuum that slowly gets colder, several of these events show abrupt rises shortly after explosion, as well as periods in which the interaction increases or decreases abruptly. These may be suitable for time-delay measurements, but they will be the focus of future research. Because these gLSNe will be so numerous, increased focus should be placed on maximizing their scientific return.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s4-6\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s4-6\">4.6.\u00a0iPTF16geu: Remarkable Fluke or Evidence of Physics Not Captured by Current Lensing Models?</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>iPTF16geu (Goobar et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib26\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib26\">2017</a>), the only gLSN\u00a0Ia with resolved images discovered to date, is notable for its remarkably high magnification. Accounting for extinction, its four supernova images had a total magnification 40\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a0<em>\u03bc</em>\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a090, significantly larger than the predicted <em>\u03bc</em>\u00a0~\u00a025 (More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib56\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib56\">2017</a>). Amplification by unresolved lens galaxy stars (microlensing) was proposed as an explanation for this anomaly (More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib56\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib56\">2017</a>). In a subsequent investigation, Yahalomi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib89\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib89\">2017</a>) used ray-tracing simulations to show that microlensing alone could not account for the large observed flux anomalies. This may indicate that the anomaly is due to millilensing, but a systematic study of millilensing induced by lens-galaxy substructures on gLSNe has yet to be performed.</p><p>Thus the origin of the large magnification of iPTF16geu remains a mystery, but the simulations presented in this paper can help place this discrepancy in context. iPTF, the survey that found iPTF16geu, used the same telescope as ZTF (the P48) to observe the same region of sky to roughly the same depth, but at a lower cadence. Thus the ZTF results presented here should be quite similar to those for iPTF. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f37\">37</a> shows the joint distribution of <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> and <em>\u03bc</em><sub>tot</sub> for gLSNe\u00a0Ia discovered in ZTF, showing that iPTF16geu is significantly more magnified than expected for its redshift (&gt;5<em>\u03c3</em>). Was iPTF16geu a remarkable fluke, or is there fundamental physics at play that our models for lensing do not capture? Searches for new strongly lensed SNe with ZTF will likely resolve this intriguing question.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjsab1fe0s5\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s5\">5.\u00a0Conclusion</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In this article, we have presented detailed simulations of the gLSN population and made predictions of the properties and rates of gLSNe that forthcoming synoptic time-domain imaging surveys will find. ZTF should discover roughly 20 gLSNe over the course of a three-year survey, and LSST should find roughly 3500 over its 10 yr lifetime. Most host galaxies will be multiply imaged, enabling detailed lens modeling if sufficiently deep high-resolution imaging is obtained. ZTF and LSST are sensitive to different gLSN populations. ZTF is most sensitive to compact, highly magnified quads with short time delays, whereas LSST is more sensitive to fainter doubles, which in general are less magnified and have longer delays. This will give LSST an advantage for time-delay cosmology if it can obtain the follow-up resources needed to extract spectroscopy and time delays from these transients. Our inclusion of dust decreases the expected gLSN\u00a0Ia rate over the predictions of Goldstein et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>), which did not include dust, by a factor of ~2, but the predictions remain largely consistent with those of Goldstein &amp; Nugent (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib24\">2017</a>). This study has found that gLSNe\u00a0IIn will be the most frequently discovered by both ZTF and LSST. With respect to LSST observing strategy, we find that strategies that produce dense light curves at the expense of a larger survey area can yield comparable numbers of gLSNe, but the better-sampled surveys discover these gLSNe earlier and produce higher-quality light curves.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f36\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f36\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f36_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 36.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 36.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f36_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 36.</strong>\u00a0Lensed host galaxy property distributions for the three surveys considered in this analysis. Red vertical lines indicate medians. The quantity <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>hl</em></sub> gives the separation between the unlensed position of the host galaxy centroid and the lens galaxy centroid in units of the Einstein radius <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>E</em></sub>. Hosts with centroids separated from the lens centroid by less than 2<em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>E</em></sub> (green dashed line) have a significant likelihood of being multiply imaged and can thus provide significant constraints on the lens model after the supernova has faded.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f36\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f36\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f36\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f36\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f37\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f37\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f37_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 37.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 37.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f37_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 37.</strong>\u00a0Joint distribution of lensing amplification and source redshift for gLSNe\u00a0Ia found by the simulated ZTF survey and lensed by smooth galaxy lenses. iPTF16geu, marked with a blue star, was dramatically more magnified than expected at its redshift. Additional events are necessary to address the origin of this discrepancy.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f37\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f37\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f37\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f37\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div>\n<div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>D.A.G. gratefully acknowledges Masamune Oguri for sharing the <tt>glafic</tt>\u00a0source code, which made the Monte Carlo simulations in this paper significantly more efficient, an anonymous referee for comments that significantly improved the clarity of the paper, Ravi Gupta for useful conversations about supernova host galaxies, Tom Collett for improving the deflector mass model, Eric Bellm for sharing his simulated ZTF survey, and Rollin Thomas and Shane Canon for assistance with <tt>shifter</tt>\u00a0at NERSC. D.A.G. acknowledges support from Hubble Fellowship grant HST-HF2-51408.001-A. Support for program number HST-HF2-51408.001-A is provided by NASA through a grant from the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy under NASA contract NAS5-26555. A.G. acknowledges funding from the Swedish Research Council and the Swedish National Space Agency. D.A.G. and P.E.N. acknowledge support from the DOE under grant DE-AC02-05CH11231, Analytical Modeling for Extreme-Scale Computing Environments. This research used resources of the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center, a DOE Office of Science User Facility supported by the Office of Science of the U.S. Department of Energy under Contract No. DE-AC02-05CH11231.</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjsab1fe0fn1\" id=\"apjsab1fe0fn1\">6\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://cs.nyu.edu/~roweis/notes/gaussid.pdf\">https://cs.nyu.edu/~roweis/notes/gaussid.pdf</a>, Equation 5(d).</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjsab1fe0fn2\" id=\"apjsab1fe0fn2\">7\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>An exact, computationally inexpensive method of calculating <em>b</em><sub><em>n</em></sub> for a given value of <em>n</em> is to evaluate <tt>gammaincinv(2</tt> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lowast.gif\" alt=\"lowast\" align=\"baseline\" /> <tt>n, 0.5)</tt> in <tt>scipy</tt>.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjsab1fe0fn3\" id=\"apjsab1fe0fn3\">8\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>See Footnote 7, but with the substitutions <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn29.gif\" alt=\"${b}_{n}\\to x$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{b}_{n}\\to x</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn30.gif\" alt=\"${\\mathtt{gammaincinv}}({\\mathtt{2}}\\,\\ast \\,{\\mathtt{n}},{\\mathtt{0}}.{\\mathtt{5}})\\to {\\mathtt{gammaincinv}}({\\mathtt{2}}\\,\\ast \\,{\\mathtt{n}},{\\mathtt{z}})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mathtt{gammaincinv}}({\\mathtt{2}}\\,\\ast \\,{\\mathtt{n}},{\\mathtt{0}}.{\\mathtt{5}})\\to {\\mathtt{gammaincinv}}({\\mathtt{2}}\\,\\ast \\,{\\mathtt{n}},{\\mathtt{z}})</script></span></span>.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjsab1fe0fn4\" id=\"apjsab1fe0fn4\">9\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://github.com/kbarbary/sfdmap\">https://github.com/kbarbary/sfdmap</a>\n</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjsab1fe0fn5\" id=\"apjsab1fe0fn5\">10\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>Public alerts can be retrieved from\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://ztf.uw.edu\">http://ztf.uw.edu</a>.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjsab1fe0fn6\" id=\"apjsab1fe0fn6\">11\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.gurobi.com/\">http://www.gurobi.com/</a>\n</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjsab1fe0fn7\" id=\"apjsab1fe0fn7\">12\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>The yields of gLSNe\u00a0IIn appear to be higher in <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> than in <tt>altsched</tt>, but this is an artifact of the high redshifts needed to fully simulate the gLSN\u00a0IIn population. The lower limits given have the ratio of the areas of the two surveys, indicating that both <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> and <tt>altsched</tt> are fully probing the population to <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a03. With an accurate model of the supernova rate at extremely high redshifts, it is likely that both <tt>minion</tt>_<tt>1016</tt> and <tt>altsched</tt> would converge to similar gLSN\u00a0IIn yields.</p></p></div></li></ul>\n\t\t</div>\n\t<!-- End Footnotes -->\t\n<!-- Start References List -->\n\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon exp-w-hash references\">\n <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0067-0049\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/90b2f21b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apjs-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8b67a84c-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8b67a84c-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The\u00a0mission\u00a0of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p>\n \n<p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/db8e6530-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/db8e6530-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">Rates and Properties of Supernovae Strongly Gravitationally Lensed by Elliptical Galaxies in Time-domain Imaging Surveys</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Daniel A. Dates -->\n<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-dates\">\n        <div class=\"replica-h4\">Dates</div>\n        <p>\n            \n                Received <span itemprop=\"dateReceived\">2018 September 26</span><br />\n            \n                Accepted <span itemprop=\"dateAccepted\">2019 May 6</span><br />\n            \n                    Published <span class=\"overlay-set\" id=\"corridor-alerts-overlay\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel two-columns\">\n        <div id=\"innerContainer\">\n            <a          <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n
