are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0067-0049%2F243%2F1%2F6\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0067-0049/243/1/6</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>Supernovae that are strongly gravitationally lensed (gLSNe) by elliptical galaxies are powerful probes of astrophysics and cosmology that will be discovered systematically by wide-field, high-cadence imaging surveys such as the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) and the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST). Here we use pixel-level simulations that include observing strategy, target selection, supernova properties, and dust to forecast the rates and properties of gLSNe that ZTF and LSST will find. Applying the resolution-insensitive discovery strategy of Goldstein et al., we forecast that ZTF (LSST) can discover 0.02 (0.79) 91bg-like, 0.17 (5.92) 91T-like, 1.22 (47.84) Type Ia, 2.76 (88.51) Type IIP, 0.31 (12.78) Type IIL, and 0.36 (15.43) Type Ib/c gLSNe per year, with uncertainties dominated by uncertainties in the supernova rate. We also forecast that the surveys can discover at least 3.75 (209.32) Type IIn gLSNe per year, for a total of at least 8.60 (380.60) gLSNe per year under fiducial observing strategies. ZTF gLSNe have a median <I>z</I> <SUB> <I>s</I> </SUB>\u00a0=\u00a00.9, <I>z</I> <SUB> <I>l</I> </SUB>\u00a0=\u00a00.35, <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$| {\\mu }_{\\mathrm{tot}}| =30$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/apjsab1fe0ieqn1.gif\"></IMG>, \u0394<I>t</I> <SUB>max</SUB>\u00a0=\u00a010 days, min(<I>\u03b8</I>)\u00a0=\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />25, and <I>N</I> <SUB>img</SUB>\u00a0=\u00a04. LSST gLSNe are less compact and less magnified, with a median <I>z</I> <SUB> <I>s</I> </SUB>\u00a0=\u00a01.0, <I>z</I> <SUB> <I>l</I> </SUB>\u00a0=\u00a00.4, <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$| {\\mu }_{\\mathrm{tot}}| =6$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/apjsab1fe0ieqn2.gif\"></IMG>, \u0394<I>t</I> <SUB>max</SUB>\u00a0=\u00a025 days, min(<I>\u03b8</I>)\u00a0=\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />6, and <I>N</I> <SUB>img</SUB>\u00a0=\u00a02. We develop a model of the supernova\u2013host galaxy connection and find that the vast majority of gLSN host galaxies will be multiply imaged, enabling detailed constraints on lens models with sufficiently deep high-resolution imaging taken after the supernova has faded. We release the results of our simulations as catalogs at\u00a0<A HREF=\"http://portal.nersc.gov/project/astro250/glsne/\">http://portal.nersc.gov/project/astro250/glsne/</A>.</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0067-0049/243/1/6&doi=10.3847/1538-4365/ab1fe0&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0067-0049/243/1/6&doi=10.3847/1538-4365/ab1fe0&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019ApJS..243....6G\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2019ApJS..243....6G\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0067-0049/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjsab1fe0s1\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s1\">1.\u00a0Introduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>When a supernova explodes far behind a foreground galaxy, the galaxy's strong gravitational field can create multiple images of the supernova in different places on the sky (Einstein <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib20\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib20\">1936</a>; Zwicky <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib90\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib90\">1937</a>). Because these images travel along different geometric paths and through different gravitational potentials to reach us, they arrive at different times, and in general they can be highly magnified (Refsdal <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib65\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib65\">1964a</a>). Time delays between the multiple images of these \"strongly gravitationally lensed supernovae\" (gLSNe) can be used to measure the Hubble constant <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0(Refsdal <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib66\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib66\">1964b</a>), which is currently in tension at the 4.4<em>\u03c3</em> level (Riess et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib68\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib68\">2019</a>),\u00a0independent of the local distance ladder and the assumed cosmological model (e.g., Birrer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib7\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib7\">2019</a>). If a gLSN\u00a0is discovered before all of its images arrive, early moments of the supernova can be observed by anticipating the appearance of the remaining images (e.g., Goldstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>; Suwa <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib84\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib84\">2018</a>). These remarkable attributes make gLSNe\u00a0valuable probes of astrophysics and cosmology.</p><p>To date, only two gLSNe\u00a0with resolved images have been discovered (Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib42\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib42\">2015</a>; Goobar et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib26\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib26\">2017</a>). Neither has yielded competitive constraints on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0(but see Bonvin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib8\">2017</a>; Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib85\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib85\">2017</a>; Grillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib29\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib29\">2018</a>; Vega-Ferrero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib86\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib86\">2018</a>), nor observations of the earliest moments of the supernova light curve. However, a new generation of high-cadence, wide-field imaging surveys, exemplified by the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF; 2018\u20132021; Graham et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib91\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib91\">2019</a>), the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST; 2021\u20132033; LSST Science Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib53\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib53\">2009</a>), and the <em>Wide-Field Infrared Survey Telescope</em> (<em>WFIRST</em>; 2025\u20132031; Spergel et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib80\">2013</a>), is expected to yield thousands of gLSNe over the next decade (Goldstein &amp; Nugent <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib24\">2017</a>; Goldstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>, see also Oguri &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib60\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib60\">2010</a>). These surveys will cover enough of the sky, to sufficient depth and at high-enough cadence, to produce the first statistical samples of gLSNe. They will also be the first to employ novel detection techniques that will eliminate the need to resolve multiple images for gLSN\u00a0discovery, furthering the yield. Finally, they will implement highly tuned gLSN\u00a0filters that will lead to early discovery and minimization of false positives.</p><p>To calibrate scientific expectations for the gLSN era, reliable forecasts of gLSN yields and properties are needed. Schneider &amp; Wagoner (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib73\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib73\">1987</a>) and Linder et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib52\">1988</a>) carried out the first gLSN property forecasts, and Kolatt &amp; Bartelmann (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib45\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib45\">1998</a>), Sullivan et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib82\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib82\">2000</a>), Holz (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib37\">2001</a>), Dobler &amp; Keeton (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib19\">2006</a>), Oguri &amp; Marshall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib60\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib60\">2010</a>), Goldstein &amp; Nugent (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib24\">2017</a>), Goldstein et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>), and Shu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib78\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib78\">2018</a>) presented refined calculations. Each of these studies neglected to account for at least one of the following important effects: observing strategy and conditions, dust, discovery strategy, multiple supernova subtypes and rates, and the supernova\u2013host galaxy connection. In anticipation of the gLSN era, we present the first pixel-level Monte Carlo, ray-tracing, and image simulations of the gLSN\u00a0population to include a detailed treatment of these important effects and use them to forecast gLSN rates and properties. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2\">2</a>, we describe our models of the supernova, host galaxy, deflector, and lens galaxy populations. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s3\">3</a>, we present the results of our simulations, including gLSN\u00a0yields and time delay, brightness, and image separation distributions. We discuss the implications of our results in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s4\">4</a> and conclude in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s5\">5</a>. In our calculations, we assume a Planck Collaboration et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib64\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib64\">2016</a>) cosmology.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjsab1fe0s2\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2\">2.\u00a0Population Models</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In this section, we describe the models of the deflector, lens galaxy, supernova, and host galaxy populations that we use to forecast the rates and properties of gLSNe\u00a0from upcoming surveys.</p><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-1\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-1\">2.1.\u00a0Deflectors</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Although galaxy clusters and late-type galaxies can act as gravitational lenses for background supernovae, we consider only elliptical galaxies as lenses in this analysis. In addition to being the most common type of gravitational lens, dominating the lensing cross section over clusters and late-type galaxies, ellipticals are the only lens galaxies that are compatible with the discovery strategy we use in our forecasts (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-9\">2.9</a>), and their mass profiles are simpler to model than those of galaxy clusters, making them ideal for cosmological analyses. The gLSN yields presented in this article are therefore lower limits on the true achievable gLSN yields of future surveys.</p><p>We model the projected mass distribution of elliptical galaxies as a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE; Kormann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib47\">1994</a>), which has shown excellent agreement with observations (e.g., Koopmans et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib46\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib46\">2009</a>). The SIE convergence <em>\u03ba</em> is given by</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\kappa (x,y)=\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\theta }_{E}}{2}\\displaystyle \\frac{\\lambda (e)}{\\sqrt{{\\left(1-e\\right)}^{-1}{x}^{2}+(1-e){y}^{2}}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\theta }_{E}=4\\pi {\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{\\sigma }{c}\\right)}^{2}\\displaystyle \\frac{{D}_{{ls}}}{{D}_{s}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>In the above equations, <em>\u03c3</em>\u00a0is the velocity dispersion of the lens galaxy, <em>e</em> is its ellipticity, and <em>\u03bb</em>(<em>e</em>) is its so-called \"dynamical normalization,\" a parameter related to three-dimensional shape, and <em>D</em><sub><em>ls</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> are the angular diameter distances between the lens and the source and the observer and the source, respectively. Here we make the simplifying assumption that there are an equal number of oblate and prolate galaxies, which Chae (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib12\">2003</a>) showed implies <em>\u03bb</em>(<em>e</em>)\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a01. We model the velocity distribution of elliptical galaxies as a modified Schechter function (Sheth et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib77\">2003</a>):</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}\\begin{array}{rcl}{dn} & = & \\phi (\\sigma )d\\sigma ={\\phi }_{* }{\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{\\sigma }{{\\sigma }_{* }}\\right)}^{\\alpha }\\exp \\left[-{\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{\\sigma }{{\\sigma }_{* }}\\right)}^{\\beta }\\right]\\\\ & & \\times \\ \\displaystyle \\frac{\\beta }{{\\rm{\\Gamma }}(\\alpha /\\beta )}\\displaystyle \\frac{d\\sigma }{\\sigma },\\end{array}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where \u0393 is the gamma function, and <em>dn</em> is the differential number of galaxies per unit velocity dispersion per unit comoving volume. Thus for the lens velocity dispersion distribution, we have</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn4\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn4.gif\" alt=\"Equation (4)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\sigma \\sim \\phi (\\sigma ).\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t4\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We adopt the parameter values Choi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib14\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib14\">2007</a>) derived from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS): (<em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em><sub>*</sub>, <em>\u03c3</em><sub>*</sub>, <em>\u03b1</em>, <em>\u03b2</em>)\u00a0=\u00a0(8\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>10<sup>\u22123</sup> <em>h</em><sup>3</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22123</sup>, 161 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, 2.32, 2.67). We assume the mass distribution and velocity function do not evolve with redshift, consistent with the results of Chae (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib13\">2007</a>), Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib59\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib59\">2008</a>), and Bezanson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib6\">2011</a>). Following Collett (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib15\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib15\">2015</a>), we draw the lens ellipticity from a velocity dispersion-dependent Rayleigh density:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn5\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn5.gif\" alt=\"Equation (5)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&e| \\sigma \\sim \\displaystyle \\frac{e}{{s}^{2}}\\exp \\left(-\\displaystyle \\frac{{e}^{2}}{{s}^{2}}\\right),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t5\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where the scale parameter <em>s</em>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>A</em>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>B\u03c3</em>, and the fit values are <em>A</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.38 and <em>B</em>\u00a0=\u00a05.7\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> (km s<sup>\u22121</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>. To exclude highly flattened mass profiles, we truncate the distribution at <em>e</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.8. We assume the deflectors have a random orientation, so for the position angle <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>e</em></sub> distribution, we have</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn6\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn6.gif\" alt=\"Equation (6)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\theta }_{e}\\sim U[0,2\\pi ].\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t6\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>We simulate the effect of lensing by line-of-sight structures as an external shear term in the deflection potential (e.g., Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib44\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib44\">1991</a>; Keeton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib39\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib39\">1997</a>; Witt &amp; Mao <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib87\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib87\">1997</a>). The deflection potential <em>\u03c8</em> of the external shear is given by</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn7\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn7.gif\" alt=\"Equation (7)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\psi (x,y)=\\displaystyle \\frac{\\gamma }{2}({x}^{2}-{y}^{2})\\cos 2{\\theta }_{\\gamma }+\\gamma {xy}\\sin 2{\\theta }_{\\gamma },\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t7\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>\u03b3</em> is the magnitude of the shear, and <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>\u03b3</em></sub> describes its orientation in the image plane. We assume the shear has a random orientation and a Rayleigh distribution in magnitude with scale parameter <em>s</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.05 (Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib88\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib88\">2011</a>). Thus the <em>\u03b3</em> distribution is</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn8\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn8.gif\" alt=\"Equation (8)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\gamma \\sim \\displaystyle \\frac{\\gamma }{{s}^{2}}\\exp \\left(-\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\gamma }^{2}}{{s}^{2}}\\right),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t8\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>with <em>s</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.05. As the shear orientation is assumed to be random, the <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>\u03b3</em></sub> distribution is</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn9\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn9.gif\" alt=\"Equation (9)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\theta }_{\\gamma }\\sim U[0,2\\pi ].\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t9\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>The lens redshift distribution can be derived from Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn3\">3</a>), which gives the differential number of galaxies per unit velocity dispersion per unit comoving volume. We begin with the definition of the comoving volume element,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn10\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn10.gif\" alt=\"Equation (10)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{{dV}}_{C}={D}_{H}\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\left(1+{z}_{l}\\right)}^{2}{D}_{l}^{2}}{E({z}_{l})}\\,{{dz}}_{l}d{\\rm{\\Omega }},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t10\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>D</em><sub><em>H</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>c</em>/<em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is the Hubble distance, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn3.gif\" alt=\"$E({z}_{l})\\,=\\sqrt{{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{M}{\\left(1+{z}_{l}\\right)}^{3}+{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">E({z}_{l})\\,=\\sqrt{{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{M}{\\left(1+{z}_{l}\\right)}^{3}+{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}}</script></span></span> in our assumed cosmology, and <em>D</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> is the angular diameter distance to the lens. Since <em>dn</em>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>dN</em>/<em>dV</em><sub><em>C</em></sub>, we can combine Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn3\">3</a>) with Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn10\">10</a>) to derive the unnormalized, all-sky (<em>d</em>\u03a9\u00a0=\u00a04<em>\u03c0</em>) redshift and velocity dispersion function:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn11\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn11.gif\" alt=\"Equation (11)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\displaystyle \\frac{{dN}}{d\\sigma {{dz}}_{l}}=4\\pi {D}_{H}\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\left(1+{z}_{l}\\right)}^{2}{D}_{l}^{2}}{E({z}_{l})}\\phi (\\sigma ).\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t11\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>As <em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em>(<em>\u03c3</em>) has no dependence on <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>, we can marginalize <em>\u03c3</em> out of Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn11\">11</a>) and drop constants to obtain an unnormalized density for <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn12\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn12.gif\" alt=\"Equation (12)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\displaystyle \\frac{{dN}}{{{dz}}_{l}}\\propto \\displaystyle \\frac{{\\left(1+{z}_{l}\\right)}^{2}{D}_{l}^{2}}{E({z}_{l})}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t12\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We normalize Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn12\">12</a>) by a constant, <em>K</em>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn13\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn13.gif\" alt=\"Equation (13)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&K={\\int }_{{z}_{l,\\min }}^{{z}_{l,\\max }}\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\left(1+{z}_{l}\\right)}^{2}{D}_{l}^{2}}{E({z}_{l})}\\,{{dz}}_{l},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t13\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em>,min</sub> and <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em>,max</sub> are the minimum and maximum lens redshifts considered in the simulation, respectively. We combine Equations (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn12\">12</a>) and (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn13\">13</a>) to obtain the probability density function for <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn14\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn14.gif\" alt=\"Equation (14)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&p({z}_{l})=\\displaystyle \\frac{1}{K}\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\left(1+{z}_{l}\\right)}^{2}{D}_{l}^{2}}{E({z}_{l})}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t14\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Finally, as a matter of convention, we always take the SIE mass profile centroid coordinates <em>x</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> and <em>y</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> to be</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn15\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn15.gif\" alt=\"Equation (15)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{x}_{l}=0,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t15\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn16\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn16.gif\" alt=\"Equation (16)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{y}_{l}=0.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t16\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>With sampling prescriptions for <em>e</em>, <em>\u03b3</em>, <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>\u03b3</em></sub>, <em>\u03c3</em>, <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>, <em>x</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>, <em>y</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>, and <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>, we can realize deflectors at random.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-2\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-2\">2.2.\u00a0Lens Galaxies</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We use the fundamental plane (Djorgovski &amp; Davis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib18\">1987</a>), a canonical relation between the mass, size, and brightness of elliptical galaxies, to assign light profiles to lens galaxies. Throughout this section, we assume the variables <em>e</em>, <em>\u03b3</em>, <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>\u03b3</em></sub>, <em>\u03c3</em>, <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>, <em>x</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>, <em>y</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>, and <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>e</em></sub> have already been sampled as described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-1\">2.1</a>. As an ansatz, we model the lens galaxy light profiles as S\u00e9rsic functions with <em>n</em>\u00a0=\u00a04 (S\u00e9rsic <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib75\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib75\">1963</a>). Such profiles have shown excellent agreement with observations of ellipticals (Lackner &amp; Gunn <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib48\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib48\">2012</a>). Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-4\">2.4</a> includes a more detailed discussion of S\u00e9rsic functions, but for now it is only important that they are specified by seven parameters: an amplitude <em>I</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>, a size parameter <em>R</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>, a shape parameter <em>n</em>, a centroid position (here <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn4.gif\" alt=\"${x}_{l}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{x}_{l}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn5.gif\" alt=\"${y}_{l}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{y}_{l}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span>), an ellipticity (here <em>e</em>'), and a position angle (here <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn6.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span>). The spectra of elliptical galaxies are remarkably uniform, with the primary feature being the break at 4000 \u00c5 (rest frame). Therefore, we model the spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of the lens light profiles using the one-component <tt>Elliptical</tt>\u00a0template of Kinney et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib43\">1996</a>). We assume that the ellipticities and position angles of the lens light profiles are the same as those of their corresponding mass profiles, in other words, that the light traces the mass. Therefore, for the lens galaxy light profile position angle <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn7.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span>, the lens galaxy light profile ellipticity <em>e</em>', and the lens galaxy light profile centroid coordinates <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"${x}_{l}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{x}_{l}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${y}_{l}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{y}_{l}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span>, we have</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn17\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn17.gif\" alt=\"Equation (17)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime} }={\\theta }_{e},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t17\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn18\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn18.gif\" alt=\"Equation (18)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{e}^{{\\prime} }=e,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t18\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn19\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn19.gif\" alt=\"Equation (19)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{x}_{l}^{{\\prime} }={x}_{l},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t19\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn20\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn20.gif\" alt=\"Equation (20)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{y}_{l}^{{\\prime} }={y}_{l}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t20\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Bernardi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib4\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib4\">2003</a>) express the fundamental plane as a multivariate normal relationship between the velocity dispersion <em>\u03c3</em>, the surface brightness <em>\u03bc</em>, and the effective radius <em>R</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn21\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn21.gif\" alt=\"Equation (21)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\left[\\begin{array}{c}\\mu \\\\ R\\\\ V\\end{array}\\right]\\sim { \\mathcal N }\\left(\\left[\\begin{array}{c}{\\mu }_{* ,c}\\\\ {R}_{* }\\\\ {V}_{* }\\end{array}\\right],\\left[\\begin{array}{ccc}{\\sigma }_{\\mu }^{2} & {\\sigma }_{R}{\\sigma }_{\\mu }{\\rho }_{R\\mu } & {\\sigma }_{V}{\\sigma }_{\\mu }{\\rho }_{V\\mu }\\\\ {\\sigma }_{R}{\\sigma }_{\\mu }{\\rho }_{R\\mu } & {\\sigma }_{R}^{2} & {\\sigma }_{R}{\\sigma }_{V}{\\rho }_{{RV}}\\\\ {\\sigma }_{V}{\\sigma }_{\\mu }{\\rho }_{V\\mu } & {\\sigma }_{R}{\\sigma }_{V}{\\rho }_{{RV}} & {\\sigma }_{V}^{2}\\end{array}\\right]\\right),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t21\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"$V\\equiv \\mathrm{log}\\left(\\sigma /[1\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}]\\right)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">V\\equiv \\mathrm{log}\\left(\\sigma /[1\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}]\\right)</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"$R\\equiv \\mathrm{log}\\left({R}_{e}/[1\\,{h}_{70}\\,\\mathrm{km}]\\right)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">R\\equiv \\mathrm{log}\\left({R}_{e}/[1\\,{h}_{70}\\,\\mathrm{km}]\\right)</script></span></span>, and <em>\u03bc</em><sub>*,<em>c</em></sub> is a <em>k</em>-corrected <em>\u03bc</em><sub>*</sub> defined by a correction factor <em>Q</em>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn22\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn22.gif\" alt=\"Equation (22)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\mu }_{* ,c}={\\mu }_{* }-{{Qz}}_{l}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t22\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Fitting the model to the <em>i</em>*-band photometry of a sample of roughly 9000 early-type galaxies from SDSS, Bernardi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib4\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib4\">2003</a>) find <em>\u03c3</em><sub><em>\u03bc</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.600, <em>\u03bc</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a019.40, <em>R</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.465, <em>\u03c3</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>\u00a0= 0.241, <em>V</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.201, <em>\u03c3</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.110, <em>\u03c1</em><sub><em>R\u03bc</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.753, <em>\u03c1</em><sub><em>V\u03bc</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22120.001, <em>\u03c1</em><sub><em>RV</em></sub>\u00a0= 0.542, and <em>Q</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.75. We adopt these values in our simulations.</p><p>Using a conditioning identity for multivariate Gaussians,<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0fn1\">6</a></sup>\n we can rewrite Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn21\">21</a>) to obtain the joint distribution of <em>\u03bc</em> and <em>R</em>:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn23\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn23.gif\" alt=\"Equation (23)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\begin{array}{l}\\left[\\begin{array}{c}\\mu \\\\ R\\end{array}\\right]| V\\sim { \\mathcal N }\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{V-{V}_{* }}{{\\sigma }_{V}}\\left[\\begin{array}{c}{\\mu }_{* ,c}+{\\sigma }_{\\mu }{\\rho }_{V\\mu }\\\\ {R}_{* }+{\\sigma }_{R}{\\rho }_{{RV}}\\end{array}\\right],\\right.\\\\ \\quad \\ \\left.\\left[\\begin{array}{cc}{\\sigma }_{\\mu }^{2}(1-{\\rho }_{V\\mu }^{2}) & {\\sigma }_{R}{\\sigma }_{\\mu }({\\rho }_{R\\mu }-{\\rho }_{{RV}}{\\rho }_{V\\mu })\\\\ {\\sigma }_{R}{\\sigma }_{\\mu }({\\rho }_{R\\mu }-{\\rho }_{{RV}}{\\rho }_{V\\mu }) & {\\sigma }_{R}^{2}(1-{\\rho }_{{RV}}^{2})\\end{array}\\right]\\right).\\end{array}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t23\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Using Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn23\">23</a>), we sample <em>\u03bc</em>, <em>R</em> pairs given the velocity dispersion <em>\u03c3</em>. We then convert <em>\u03bc</em> into an <em>i</em>-band apparent AB magnitude <em>m</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> using the following relation from Bernardi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib4\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib4\">2003</a>):</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn24\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn24.gif\" alt=\"Equation (24)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}\\begin{array}{rcl}{m}_{i} & = & \\mu -5\\mathrm{log}\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{R}_{e}/{D}_{l}}{1^{\\prime\\prime} }\\right)-2.5\\mathrm{log}(2\\pi )\\\\ & & +\\ 10\\mathrm{log}(1+{z}_{l}).\\end{array}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t24\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We then linearly rescale the flux of the <tt>Elliptical</tt> template so that its <em>i</em>-band apparent magnitude is <em>m</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>. We assume that the spectrum of the galaxy is spatially constant, so <em>m</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> also fixes <em>I</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>. With the results of Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-1\">2.1</a> and sampling prescriptions for <em>m</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>R</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{e}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span>, <em>e</em>', <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"${x}_{l}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{x}_{l}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"${y}_{l}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{y}_{l}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span>, we can realize lens galaxy light profiles at random.</p><p>In our model of the lens galaxy population, we neglect microlensing by lens galaxy stars. Studies have shown that microlensing can cause significant errors when using gLSNe to measure time delays (Dobler &amp; Keeton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib19\">2006</a>; Goldstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>) or constrain mass models (Foxley-Marrable et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib21\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib21\">2018</a>). However, the effect of microlensing on gLSN yields has been shown to be small (Goldstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib25\">2018</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-3\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-3\">2.3.\u00a0Supernovae</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We consider seven different supernova subtypes in this analysis: Type Ia, Type IIP, Type IIn, Type IIL, Type Ib/c, SN 1991bg-like, and SN 1991T-like supernovae. Type Ia, SN 1991bg-like, and SN 1991T-like supernovae are believed to result from the thermonuclear explosions of white dwarfs (Maoz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib55\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib55\">2014</a>), whereas SNe IIP, SNe IIL, SNe Ib/c, and SNe IIn result from core collapse in massive stars. Our model of the supernova population is characterized by two global parameters for each supernova subtype: a mean peak rest-frame <em>B</em>-band absolute magnitude in the Vega system <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{{M}_{B}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{{M}_{B}}</script></span></span>, and the scatter in this magnitude <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{M}_{B}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{M}_{B}}</script></span></span>. Throughout this section, we assume that deflector and lens galaxy parameters have already been sampled as described in Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-1\">2.1</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-2\">2.2</a>. For each supernova in the simulation, we realize a peak rest-frame <em>B</em>-band absolute magnitude <em>M</em><sub><em>B</em></sub> according to</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn25\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn25.gif\" alt=\"Equation (25)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{M}_{B}\\sim { \\mathcal N }({\\mu }_{{M}_{B}},{\\sigma }_{{M}_{B}}).\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t25\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>In our Monte Carlo simulation, we randomly draw the unlensed angular position of each supernova uniformly over a circular area of angular radius <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> centered on the lens galaxy. Using another Monte Carlo simulation, we found that in more than 99.9% of cases, multiply imaged point sources had unlensed positions within 0.9<em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>E</em></sub> of the SIE centroid. Therefore, in the present calculations, we set <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.9<em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>E</em></sub>, where <em>\u03b8</em><sub><em>E</em></sub> is the lens's angular Einstein radius, which can be calculated via Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0eqn2\">2</a>). To realize random supernova positions uniformly over this area, we first draw two random deviates from the uniform distribution,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn26\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn26.gif\" alt=\"Equation (26)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&r\\sim U[0,1],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t26\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn27\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn27.gif\" alt=\"Equation (27)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\theta \\sim U[0,2\\pi ],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t27\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>then convert these into lens-centered Euclidean angular coordinates <em>x</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> and <em>y</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> via</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn28\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn28.gif\" alt=\"Equation (28)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{x}_{s}={\\theta }_{l}\\sqrt{r}\\cos \\theta ,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t28\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn29\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn29.gif\" alt=\"Equation (29)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{y}_{s}={\\theta }_{l}\\sqrt{r}\\sin \\theta .\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t29\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>This ensures that supernovae are realized uniformly over each lens's area of influence. We draw a redshift for each supernova from the functions <em>f</em><sub><em>T</em></sub>(<em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>) shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f1\">1</a>. The normalized Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f1\">1</a> curves <em>S</em><sub><em>T</em></sub>(<em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>) give the redshift probability density function for supernova type <em>T</em>,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn30\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn30.gif\" alt=\"Equation (30)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&p({z}_{s})={S}_{T}({z}_{s}),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t30\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> is the source redshift. For each supernova subtype, we assume that the spectral evolution is described by a template with one parameter (the overall normalization), and we use the realized <em>M</em><sub><em>B</em></sub> to set its value assuming the Planck Collaboration et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib64\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib64\">2016</a>) cosmology described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s1\">1</a>. With sampling prescriptions for <em>M</em><sub><em>B</em></sub>, <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>, <em>x</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>, and <em>y</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>, we can realize supernovae at random. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t1\">1</a> lists the references for our supernova templates, rates, and luminosity functions.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjsab1fe0t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nDetails of the Supernova Population Model\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0t1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table }_{{M}_{B}}</script></span></span>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Template</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Template (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib83\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib83\">2006</a>)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">91T</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">\u221219.3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Nugent-91T</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Nugent et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib57\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib57\">2002</a>)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Sullivan et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib83\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib83\">2006</a>)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">IIL</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">\u221217.46</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.38</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Nugent-IIL</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Gilliland et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib22\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib22\">1999</a>)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Li et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib51\">2011</a>)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">IIn</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">\u221219.05</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Nugent-IIn</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Gilliland et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib22\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib22\">1999</a>)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Li et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib51\">2011</a>)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Ibc</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">\u221217.51</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.74</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Nugent-Ibc</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Levan et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib50\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib50\">2005</a>)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Li et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib51\">2011</a>)</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong>\u00a0Magnitudes are given in the Vega system.</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4365/ab1fe0\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/suppdata/apjsab1fe0t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0All-sky supernova rates as a function of redshift (observer frame). In our simulations, supernova redshifts are realized at random from these distributions. The references in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t1\">1</a> provide the data sources of these curves.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f1\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f1\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The supernova rate curves shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f1\">1</a> were obtained by fixing theoretical models of the supernova rate to actual supernova rate measurements at fiducial redshifts. In the present calculations, we assume that the redshift-dependent core-collapse supernova rate (used above for SNe IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ib/c) is directly proportional to the cosmic star formation rate. We make this assumption because the delay time between the formation and death of stars that explode as core-collapse supernovae (in megayears) is much smaller than the characteristic timescale over which the star formation rate evolves (gigayears). The redshift-dependent thermonuclear supernova rate is taken to follow the SFH-II model of Pain et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib61\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib61\">2002</a>). These curves are normalized to the core-collapse and thermonuclear rate measurements at fiducial redshifts from the references in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0t1\">1</a>, with the relative breakdown of supernova subtypes taken from Richardson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib67\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib67\">2014</a>). Although the redshift dependence of the supernova rate is well constrained on observational and theoretical grounds, the overall normalization of the supernova rate is associated with significant uncertainty, at the level of tens of percent. For example, Bazin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib3\">2009</a>) measured the core-collapse supernova rate at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.3 with an uncertainty of roughly 30%. As the yields we present in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s3\">3</a> are linearly dependent on the overall normalization of the supernova rate (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-10\">2.10</a>), and because this is the dominant uncertainty in our analysis, our yields should be taken to be uncertain by approximately this factor.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjsab1fe0s2-4\" name=\"apjsab1fe0s2-4\">2.4.\u00a0Host Galaxies</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The connection between supernovae and their host galaxies is of critical importance to time-delay cosmology with gLSNe, as lensed host galaxy arcs will provide significant leverage on lens models (e.g., Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib85\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib85\">2017</a>). Here we describe an empirical model of the supernova\u2013host galaxy connection that we use to realize hosts for each supernova in our simulation. Throughout this section, we assume that deflector, lens galaxy, and supernova parameters have already been sampled as described in Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-1\">2.1</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0s2-3\">2.3</a>. We consider three types of host galaxies: elliptical galaxies, which have almost no ongoing star formation, S0/a-Sb galaxies, which have a moderate level of ongoing star formation, and late-type/spiral galaxies, which have vigorous ongoing star formation. As an ansatz, we take the light profiles of the host galaxies in the absence of lensing to be S\u00e9rsic functions with <em>n</em>\u00a0=\u00a0{1, 1, 4}, respectively. Only normal SNe\u00a0Ia and SN 1991bg-like events have been observed to be hosted by elliptical or S0/a-Sb galaxies. Based on measured rates, we assume these two subclasses of thermonuclear supernovae have a 30% chance of being hosted by an elliptical, a 35% chance of being hosted by an S0/a-Sb, and a 35% chance of being hosted by a late-type/spiral, roughly consistent with the results of Han et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib33\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib33\">2010</a>), Li et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib51\">2011</a>), Hakobyan et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib32\">2012</a>), and Smith et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib79\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib79\">2012</a>). In our simulations, Type Ib/c, Type IIP, Type IIL, Type IIn, and SN 1991T-like supernovae can only be hosted by late-type/spiral galaxies. For simplicity, we assume the spectra of the host galaxies are given by the following Kinney et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib43\">1996</a>) templates: <tt>Elliptical</tt>\u00a0(elliptical), <tt>Sc</tt>\u00a0(S0/a-Sb), and <tt>Starburst</tt>\u00a0(late-type/spiral).</p><p>We draw the host galaxy luminosities from two separate luminosity functions: one for the hosts of thermonuclear supernovae (SNe\u00a0Ia, SN 1991bg-like, and SN 1991T-like events) and one for the hosts of core-collapse supernovae. We construct both of our luminosity functions using supernovae discovered by the Palomar Transient Factory (PTF; Law et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib49\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib49\">2009</a>). PTF discovered thousands of supernovae to <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a00.1 and obtained spectral confirmation of many of them in a relatively unbiased manner. For the core-collapse supernovae, we draw the cosmology-independent host galaxy rest-frame <em>R</em>-band absolute magnitude <em>M</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a05 log <em>h</em> at random from the sample of Arcavi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib2\">2010</a>) confined to 0.01\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a00.05 to limit the effects of peculiar velocities and to ensure a complete sample. For the thermonuclear events, we use a catalog compiled by E. Y. Hsiao &amp; P. E. Nugent (2019, private communication) drawn from the PTF discoveries that overlapped with fields observed by SDSS and the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey.</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0f2\">2</a> shows the luminosity functions of core-collapse and thermonuclear supernova host galaxies used in the present calculations. The host galaxy redshift <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{s}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{s}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> is fixed to the redshift of the supernova</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn31\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn31.gif\" alt=\"Equation (31)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{z}_{s}^{{\\prime} }={z}_{s}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t31\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>The sampled values of <em>M</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a05 log <em>h</em> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{s}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{s}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> fix the normalization of the host galaxy spectral template and the host galaxy S\u00e9rsic profile amplitude under the assumption of a Planck Collaboration et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib64\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib64\">2016</a>) cosmology.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjsab1fe0f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjsab1fe0f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Host galaxy luminosity functions used in our simulations.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjsab1fe0f2\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjsab1fe0f2\" href=\"/0067-0049/243/1/6/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjsab1fe0f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Following Shen et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjsab1fe0bib76\" id=\"fnref-apjsab1fe0bib76\">2003</a>), we take the sizes and intrinsic brightnesses of galaxies to be correlated via the \"size\u2013luminosity relation\"</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjsab1fe0eqn32\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0eqn32.gif\" alt=\"Equation (32)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&p(\\mathrm{log}\\,{R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }| {M}_{R})={ \\mathcal N }(\\mathrm{log}\\,{\\bar{R}}_{e},{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{log}{R}_{e}}),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t32\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"${R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{R}_{e}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> is the effective radius of the host galaxy S\u00e9rsic profile, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"${\\bar{R}}_{e}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\bar{R}}_{e}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0067-0049/243/1/6/Full/apjsab1fe0ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{log}{R}_{e}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{log}{R}_{e}}</script></span></span> are global parameters. Shen et al.
